projectDescription: SMURFs are artificial collectors that are placed in the water and used to attract young invertebrates (crabs, urchins, lobsters) and fish. The SMURFs were moored both near the bottom and the surface for a year. Once a month the SMURFs were brought up to count invertebrates. During June to September when fish recruitment season peaks the SMURFs were brought up biweekly to count fish. Since 2000, the SMURFs have been used to monitor recruitment of fishes throughout the Santa Barbara Channel and the Northern Channel Islands. This technique has been successful for determining the number of fish that were settling in particular areas throughout this region. projectDescription:
On June 24, 1989, the Presidente Rivera, a 749 foot Uruguayan tanker, ran aground in the Delaware River on Claymont Shoal, near Naamans Creek. The ship was carrying 18 million gallons of No. 6 fuel oil and was preparing to dock. The grounding resulted in the opening of four if its 17 cargo tanks, releasing approximately 306,000 gallons of oil.  The DNREC 1989 pre-assessment Screen Report on the spill reports that 22 miles of riverine and estuarine shoreline was impacted by the oil. The No. 6 fuel oil was a highly viscous oil, and formed a thick coating upon contact with the shoreline.  Vegetation along 22 miles of Delaware River and Bay shoreline were impacted in widths of 5-20 feet.

projectDescription: Saw Mill Creek Marsh Preserve is a 135-acre complex of salt marshes, swamp forests and sandy coastal hummocks adjacent to the Arthur Kill tidal straight in Staten Island NY. An area of 4 acres of formerly connected tidal marsh was separated from diurnal tidal flow by an earthen dike wall, which had been constructed around the 1950s. This marsh system had received infrequent tidal exchange through one main breach in the dike wall. Sedimentation had increased behind the dike wall, resulting in an expansion of common reed (Phragmites australis) into half of the marsh area (2 acres). The restoration plan removed the dike wall to allow tidal flow into the interior. This effort was funded through the DARRP program from the Exxon Bayway oil spill settlement, as well as a contribution from the New York State Environmental Protection Fund.

projectDescription:
MSRP is re-establishing the Cassin’s Auklet breeding population and restoring the state-threatened Scripps’s Murrelet on Santa Barbara Island (SBI). The Cassin’s Auklet population was decimated by cats that were introduced to the island in the late 1800s. Efforts to re-establish the Cassin’s Auklet colony include using social attraction methods, installing nest boxes, and improving habitat through the removal of non-native vegetation from historical nesting areas and revegetation with native plants.

SBI is home to the largest colony of Scripps’s Murrelets in California despite a documented population decline over the last 20 years. Some Scripps’s Murrelet nest sites have been lost due to a reduction in shrub cover on Santa Barbara Island. This restoration project aims to increase the amount of suitable nesting habitat for this species.

projectDescription: The Liberty Industrial Finishing (LIF) Superfund settlement resulted in a project that addressed compensation for natural resource injuries stemming from release of hazardous substances at the former manufacturing facility in Long Island.  The project restored migratory fish passage at Massapequa Creek at the spillway downstream of Massapequa Lake.  Two architectural stone and concrete spillways prevented river herring and other fish species from passing from the estuarine habitat of the Lower Massapequa Creek to the freshwater habitat of Massapequa Lake and Creek.   A fish ladder was constructed to provide passage to 40 acres of freshwater spawning habitat.  Monitoring was conducted at the site to determine presence/absence of target species. Between 2009-2014 NOAA's cooperative agreement with the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation (NFWF) provided for a contract with Seatuck Environmental, a local non-profit group, to monitor and maintain the ladder in good working order. During the monitoring period river herring were found to be utilizing the fish ladder to migrate upstream. In August 2015 NOAA RC staff made an independent inspection of the ladder with members of Seatuck Environmental and confirmed the presence of juvenile Young-of-the-Year (YOY) Alewife in the lake.

projectDescription:
The primary goal of this project was to restore hydrology to approximately 175 acres of DE state- owned land north of Pickering Beach Road. Currently this area is void of daily tidal exchange. Historical inlets to the Delaware Bay no longer exist on the eastern portion of the marsh, while the remainder of the marsh is bound by existing roads and impoundment dike at the north, west, and southern boundaries of the marsh.  The project involved the restoration of a previously existing north to south ditch of approximately 1.3 miles running from the Little Creek Main Impoundment at the north to the existing Lewis Ditch at the south.

A second component of this project involved the replacement of a non-functioning water control structure located along the southern dike of the Little Creek Main Impoundment adjacent to the Pickering Marsh.  Due to limited flow through the Pickering Marsh, this secondary water control structure on the impoundment has not been placed in use and is currently in need of replacement. A functioning structure at this location would allow for tidal flow through the impoundment during portions of the year serving as a benefit to fisheries in addition to improving the health of the impounded wetland habitat to the benefit of an abundance of wildlife utilizing the area.

projectDescription:
On January 1, 1990, approximately 567,000 gallons of No. 2 fuel oil discharged from a ruptured pipeline in the Arthur Kill waterway in New York Harbor. Over 100 acres of salt marsh was oiled on the Staten Island and New Jersey shorelines causing extensive mortality to vegetation, fish and wildlife. A settlement was reached for $12.5 million in 1991. Funds from combined cases (BT Nautilus and Cibro Savanah) have been used to restore injured wetlands in NY and NJ. 

The tidal wetland restoration at Bridge Creek, Staten Island (a tributary to the Arthur Kill waterway) was completed in 2006 to provide alteration of hydrologic regime (channel formation) affecting current flow, velocity, volume, tidal amplitude and flow patterns in Bridge Creek. The project manipulated a 22.67 acre site and restored tidal flow and removed invasive Phragmites to 20 acres of salt marsh and created a 2.67 capped disposal upland island adjacent.  The project hand planted 13 acres of Spartina alterniflora.  Fish and Bird Utilization and Vegetation Growth were measured under the monitoring program conducted by NYSDEC and assisted by the NOAA Restoration Center.

projectDescription: On January 7, 1994, the barge Morris J. Berman, grounded on a reef off Punta Escambron, releasing approximately 800,000 gallons of fuel oil into coastal waters near San Juan, Puerto Rico. About one week later, a secondary release of nearly 125,000 gallons of an oil/water mixture occurred during and after removal operations and vessel scuttling. The oil spread along the northern coast of Puerto Rico, injuring natural and historic resources along the shoreline.  More than 100 miles of ocean and 66 miles of bay shorelines were oiled.  The Condado Coral Trail Project helped restore lost reef services resulting from this grounding and spill by placing 45 coral reef modules in a snorkeling trail formation within the Condado Lagoon.  In addition, the San Juan Bay Estuary Partnership implemented an education and outreach campaign describing the significance of the project and installed project signage along the public beach that overlooks the project site.
primaryStrategy: Coral

projectDescription: The goal of this large-scale kelp forest restoration project is to reduce the abundance of urchins from 95 acres of identified urchin barrens along the Palos Verdes Shelf area to a level that represents a healthy kelp forest habitat. Kelp forests in the area have experienced a 75% loss of kelp canopy, and nearly 100 acres of reef habitat along the Palos Verdes coast is instead covered by “urchin barrens,” where the densities of urchins are extremely high and kelp plants are non-existent. To bring back the kelp forests, volunteer divers, commercial urchin divers, researchers, and local non-profit groups will assist SMBRF with removing urchins from the “urchin barrens” and allow for natural settlement of kelp plants. Permits for collection of urchins and to conduct research were obtained in July 2013 and urchin removal began shortly after obtaining permits. Monitoring of the urchin barrens will also take place to measure the increase in kelp forest habitat.
primaryStrategy: Does not fall under a strategy
name: Montrose - Palos Verde Shelf Kelp Restoration Project

projectDescription:
On January 1, 1990, approximately 567,000 gallons of No. 2 fuel oil discharged from a ruptured pipeline in the Arthur Kill waterway in New York Harbor. Over 100 acres of salt marsh were oiled on the Staten Island and New Jersey shorelines causing extensive mortality to vegetation, fish and wildlife. A settlement was reached for $12.5 million in 1991. Funds from combined cases (BT Nautilus and Cibro Savanah) have been used to restore injured wetlands in NY and NJ. 

The LP West Wetland Project constructed a 42 acre restoration site at a former municipal 90-acre landfill (Jersey City). The Exxon Bayway fund provided $250,000 to planning and design - completed in Sept 2009. The total project construction cost was $13.6 million provided by the ARRA of 2009 ($10.6 million), Exxon Bayway fund ($2.2 million) and NJDEP NRDA fund ($800,000). Construction began in 2010 and was concluded following a two-year monitoring effort in May of 2012. 

The project excavated 42 acres of polluted sediment and landfill to below the clean sub-surface and placed the fill under the adjacent 50 acre capped landfill as required by a NJDEP landfill closure order. The ACOE Nav Deepening Program supplied 500,000 cubic yds of clean sand by barge and pumped to an upland de-watering facility. 250,000 cu yds of sand was placed over the 42 acre excavation site and was contoured to create 24 ac wetland and tide creeks, 9 ac tidal pond, 8 acre grassland and 1 ac trail system.
primaryStrategy: Hydro Reconnection
name: Exxon Bayway Oil Spill - Lincoln Park Wetland Restoration

projectDescription: Monument Pond is a 3-acre freshwater pond located in Mariners Marsh Preserve in the northwest of Staten Island, NY. Shorebirds and wading birds, common to coastal marshes, utilize Monument Pond and six other ponds in the preserve for foraging and cover. The project consisted of control of a single invasive species, common reed or Phragmites. Hand pulling, repeat mowing and a single hand-brushed herbicide application over two years were utilized to remove the reed. One-quarter of an acre of  emergent pond habitat was rehabilitated. Plantings consisted of over one thousand seedling plugs of 25 species of emergent vegetation and hundreds of saplings of 10 species of facultative wetland shrubs and trees. The plants were placed primarily in the shallow water zone to provide the pond with a diversity of native plant material and surface structure designed to improve inland aquatic habitat for small fish, invertebrates and turtles.

projectDescription: On Saturday, June 24, 1989, the Presidente Rivera, a 749 foot Uruguayan tanker, ran aground in the Delaware River on Claymont Shoal, near Naamans Creek. The ship was carrying 18 million gallons of No. 6 fuel oil and was preparing to dock at the Sun Oil Company refinery in Marcus Hook, Pennsylvania. The grounding resulted in the opening of four if its 17 cargo tanks, releasing approximately 306,000 gallons of oil. The tanker was re-floated on Sunday, June 25, 1989, and was taken to the Sun Oil Company refinery where the remainder of its cargo was unloaded. The DNREC 1989 Pre-assessment Screen Report on the spill reported that 22 miles of riverine and estuarine shoreline was impacted by the oil. The most heavily oiled areas in the Delaware River were immediately south of the Port of Wilmington for a distance of approximately three miles. The No. 6 fuel oil spilled by the Presidente Rivera was a highly viscous oil, and formed a thick coating upon contact with the shoreline.  Vegetation along 22 miles of Delaware River and Bay shoreline were impacted in widths of 5-20 feet. Booms were strategically placed to help reduce impacts to sensitive riverbank areas and Pea Patch Island (home to the largest heron rookery on the east coast). This project included erosion stabilization along Pea Patch Island and 57 acre herbicide treatment of Phragmites removal along the southeastern portion of the island.  Over 95% of Phragmites was eliminated with no evidence of recurring invasions.

projectDescription: Joseph Medwick Park contains 16 acres of formerly connected tidal marsh separated by an earthen dike wall. The marsh receives infrequent tidal waters through two main breaches in the dike wall. Trapped sediments behind the dike wall accumulated to 1-2 feet above the reach of the tides and the resultant product was a 13-acre stand of common reed (Phragmites australis). The restoration plan called for a first phase removal of debris and trapped sediments, and a re-contouring of the interior to include such features as open water, tidal creeks and vegetated salt marsh. Upon completion of the interior, the second phase called for the removal of the dike wall to allow tidal flow into the interior. A floating debris barrier was planned for the outer rim of the project site but was later not required. DARRP funds from the Exxon Bayway oil spill settlement covered some of the design and feasibility study costs, while additional funds came from the Arthur Kill Deepening Program Mitigation Fund (ACOE). The project was ultimately built by the ACOE and completed in 2005.
primaryStrategy: Hydro Reconnection

projectDescription: DARRP funds from the Exxon Bayway oil spill settlement were awarded to New York City Parks & Recreation Natural Resources Group (NRG) to undertake an intensive study, utilizing both ground studies and remote sensing to enhance colonial wading bird nesting habitat data for Pralls Island. The possible interactions between wildlife populations and their habitat were assessed in order to determine the cause of colony collapse and identify solutions.  NRCS made assessments of soil structure and chemistry. Predator presence were performed by NRG. All 7000 trees on the island were cataloged determine nest platform suitability. New York City Audubon investigated heron utilization of the island. With this data it was determined that invasion by invasive tree species was having deleterious effect on the already complex species interactions. Data gathering supported the receipt of additional funding through the New York State CWCA Bond Act for design and construction of tree canopy enhancement on the island. A plan for invasive tree removal and replanting with suitable trees for nesting was halted by the USDA APHIS when the Asian long-horn beetle became present on the island and required an entirely different approach to eradication. APHIS removed the native trees from the island due to a demonstrated preference by the beetle for North American deciduous trees. The heron colony, though already small due to predator pressures, was lost.

projectDescription:
The goal of this restoration effort is to restore seabird habitat by removing non-native vegetation, installing artificial nesting boxes, and reducing human disturbance. Restoration is taking place off of mainland Santa Cruz Island (SCI) on Scorpion rock, Orizaba rock, and within sea caves surrounding SCI. 
Ashy Storm-petrels are rare and endemic to California and northwestern Baja California, with a world population of less than 10,000 individuals. At SCI, offshore rocks and sea caves continue to host important nesting colonies. Small colony sizes and fragile habitats make Ashy Storm-Petrels highly susceptible to natural or human impacts. MSRP restoration activities on Orizaba Rock and surrounding sea caves involve installing artificial nest sites for Ashy Storm-Petrels to provide a secure nesting habitat. Recorded vocalizations are used to attract Ashy Storm-Petrels to the artificial nests. 
Scorpion Rock is a small islet located off the northeast coast of Santa Cruz Island. Natural Cassin’s Auklet burrows are present in relatively small numbers on the rock, due to the scarce vegetation and associated high rate of soil erosion. MSRP restoration activities on Scorpion Rock has improved and enhanced existing natural habitat for Cassin’s Auklets by restoring native vegetation, stabilizing soil to minimize erosion, and removing invasive, non-native vegetation. Biologists have also installed artificial nesting habitat to provide stable and secure nest sites for Cassin’s Auklets.
primaryStrategy: Does not fall under a strategy
name: Montrose - Santa Cruz Island Seabird Restoration

projectDescription: This project involves the removal of the Bartlett Fish Rod Co. Dam located on Amethyst Brook in the Town of Pelham, Massachusetts.  The removal opened 0.6 miles of high quality upper perennial river to the next barrier, Orient Spring Dam.  This project benefits sea lamprey by improving river spawning (nest building) habitat, as well as other species such as American eel, Eastern brook trout, and slimy sculpin. projectDescription:
On April 27, 2006, the T/V MARGARA, a 748 foot Cayman Island-flagged tanker, ran aground on coral reefs off the south coast of Puerto Rico.  The vessel was removed the following day without discharging the 300,000 barrels of fuel oil that was on board.  However, efforts to refloat and remove the vessel caused significant injury to approximately two acres of seafloor inhabited by six species of coral listed as “threatened” under the Endangered Species Act.  Emergency restoration actions conducted between 2006 and 2008 reattached almost 10,000 corals and removed antifouling paint from the reef.  The emergency restoration activities, however, did not address all of the restoration that was needed at the site.

Primary Restoration at the site willl restore the coral resources, and other reef biota and habitat that were significantly injured in the grounding. The proposed restoration project involves the placement of limestone and/or large boulders on top of the rubble, followed by active transplantation of approximately 1,500 coral colonies on the substrates. The proposed plan would stabilize the rubble, return topographic complexity to the site, and accelerate the biological recovery of the injured species.
primaryStrategy: Coral
name: T/V Margara Grounding - Primary Coral Reef Restoration
darrpResponsibility: Margara Shipping Ltd.; Shipowners Insurance and Guaranty Company

projectDescription:
A phosphogypsum stack breached at the MPI phosphoric acid and fertilizer production facility in Mulberry, Polk County, Florida on December 7, 1997. Around 50-56 million gallons of acidic process water flowed into the Alafia River and caused a fish kill in the Alafia River, damaged shoreline and upland vegetation in some areas within Polk County, and caused losses of palustrine and estuarine resource services.

The Restoration Council was formed with representation from NOAA, the FDEP and the EPC, and they jointly developed a Final Damage Assessment and Restoration Plan and Environmental Assessment. Settlement monies administered through NOAA funded the project design and implementation of an oyster reef restoration project. NOAA selected the Tetra Tech team in May 2013 to provide the engineering, environmental, geotechnical, and implementation services for the project.

The Project was permitted for 28,350 square feet (0.65 acre) of reef substrate. The total installed reef area was 21,470 square feet (0.49 acre) or 76% of the permitted reef area. The project was installed over 45 days between April 20 and June 24, 2015. A Trustee inspection on June 25, 2015 documented macroalgal and diverse invertebrate colonization of the newly installed reefs.
primaryStrategy: Shellfish
name: Mulberry Oyster Reef Creation in Hillsborough Bay

projectDescription: On December 7, 1997, over 50 million gallons of acidic process water was released into the Alafia River from a fertilizer plant in Mulberry, Polk County, Florida. The release injured natural resources in the Alafia River and in Tampa Bay. Several public agencies, including NOAA, FDEP and EPC, worked together to assess natural resource injuries and losses caused by the Spill and to recover natural resource damages to compensate for these losses from the party responsible. This project consisted of two components implemented on MacDill Airforce Base: the Mangrove/Tidal Creek project and the Lewis Lake Project.  The first component involved the restoration of 34 acres of intertidal lagoons/channels, high and low marsh platforms, mangrove islands, upland islands, upland hammocks, and relic mangrove forest. To accomplish project goals, large stands of non-native vegetation had to be removed, followed by excavation of lagoons and channels to restore tidal availability. The second component, the Lewis Lake Project, modified an existing freshwater/oligohaline stormwater treatment pond that was intermittently intertidal via the pond’s overflow control structure. This 26.6 acre project increased the size of the pond, created new open water and marsh platforms, removed all cattails and other nuisance/non-native plants from marsh platforms, and resulted in improved water quality for the bay due to enhanced stormwater treatment capacity of the pond.

projectDescription: The Weston Mill Dam Removal on the Millstone River was completed as part of the Raritan River Fish Passage Initiative, a partnership between NOAA, NJDEP and various stakeholders. The Weston Mill Dam was part of a former mill operation located in Franklin Township NJ and spanned the towns of Manville Borough and Franklin Twp.  The American Cyanamid Superfund Trustees Restoration Plan determined that the dam was a suitable preferred alternative and partial compensation for ecological injuries stemming from in-river contaminant releases at the former American Cyanamid facility in nearby Bridgewater NJ. Some form of dam had existed at the site since the 1700's thus blocking migratory fish passage for over 250 years. The most current version of the dam was a reinforced concrete spillway structure built in the mid 1930's.  The mill was destroyed in the early 1970's and ceased operation. The remnant mill structures are considered eligible for historic listing while the dam itself was not. Under the terms of the Natural Resources Damages Consent Decree with Wyeth Holdings (the current owner of the America Cyanamid Superfund site in Bridgewater NJ), the 3.0 foot high spillway structure was removed to allow migration of migratory fish species to the next barrier, 4.6 miles upstream on the Millstone River at Blackwell Mills. What was left of the historic mill structure was protected by rock armament. Removal was completed August 2017.

projectDescription: The Oceanic Fish Restoration Project (OFRP), previously named the Pelagic Longline Bycatch Reduction Project in the Final Phase IV Early Restoration Plan, is being implemented as a partnership between NOAA, pelagic fishermen in the Gulf of Mexico, and the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation (NFWF) to restore pelagic fish biomass through actions that are expected to reduce fish mortality from bycatch and regulatory discards in the U.S. Atlantic pelagic longline (PLL) fishery operating in the Gulf of Mexico (GOM; referred to as the GOM PLL fishery). The GOM PLL fishery primarily targets yellowfin tuna and swordfish, but incidentally catches and discards other fish, including bluefin tuna (which, by regulation, is not a target of fisheries in the GOM), marlin, sharks, and smaller individuals of the target species. The project will compensate PLL fishers who agree to voluntarily refrain from PLL fishing in the GOM during an annual six-month repose period that coincides with the bluefin tuna spawning season. The project will also provide participating vessel owners with two alternative gear types to allow for the continued harvest of yellowfin tuna and swordfish during the repose period when PLL gear is not used.  For additional information and project updates, please visit:  http://www.gulfspillrestoration.noaa.gov/project?id=58

projectDescription:
This project is restoring beach, dune, and marsh habitats. In May 2016, we began creating the barrier island. Beach and dunes were recreated between Pass Ronquille and Pass Chaland in southernmost Plaquemines Parish, using sand dredged from the Gulf of Mexico. A hydraulic dredge was used to scoop up sediment from the shoreline, mixing it with water, and pumping the mixture through a pipeline to the island. The mixture was then shaped into dune and marsh habitat by powerful earth moving equipment.

The Engineering and Design portion of this project was implemented and supported by the CWPPRA Task Force. Construction of the new marsh began in September 2016 and was completed in January 2017. Beach and dune construction began in October 2016, and the project was completed  by the end of February 2017.

The project was part of the third phase of early restoration after the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. This project restored a portion of the barrier chain that separates Barataria Basin from the Gulf of Mexico. It will help protect the coastal ecosystems and communities in the Basin from storms. It will also reduce erosion from shorelines in Barataria Bay, which were heavily impacted by the spill.

projectDescription: The goal of this project was to restore Western gull and Brandt's Cormorant colonies on the U.S. Navy owned San Nicolas Island by removing feral cats. projectDescription: The Copper River Watershed Project designed this project to analyze City of Cordova and Alaska Department of Transportation & Public Facilities’ practices for snow handling and storage, to make recommendations for changes that would reduce pollutants draining to receiving waters, to implement best management practice site improvements at up to three snow storage sites in Cordova, and to measure differences in water quality of snow meltwater before and after implementation of best snow management practices.  Because synthesized research on the long-term effects of the Exxon Valdez oil spill found that chronic persistence of oil has sub-lethal impacts on marine populations, the Copper River Watershed Project was concerned about the effects of stormwater runoff (including melting snow) on sockeye and coho populations in Eyak Lake, coho salmon in Odiak Pond, and juvenile herring in eastern Prince William Sound.  Due to unusually low amounts of snowfall during the winters of this grant period, we were unable to sample snow meltwater runoff.  We did complete a municipal and state snow handling practices analysis, improve one snow storage site and complete design of a second, and produce a snow storage guidance document for use by municipalities and state agencies.This design  was later used to complete another project.

projectDescription:
The Dockton Shoreline Restoration Project is located on Quartermaster Harbor, on Vashon-Maury Island. The project removed 80 creosote-coated pilings and other debris from an intertidal area of Quartermaster Harbor.  The project also restored beach-forming processes and salt marsh characteristics in a one-acre site along the shoreline.

Beach-forming processes and salt marsh characteristics were restored to the site by removing approximately 375 linear feet of shoreline protection (loose rock bulkhead) and about 1,700 cubic yards of fill that have been placed landward of the bulkhead. The filled area was graded to create a variety of salt water inundation frequencies and optimize potential salt marsh habitat. In addition, the upper beach area was nourished with up to 100 cubic yards of appropriately sized gravel to mitigate for the interruption of sediment supply to the beach, promote beach-forming processes and improve beach-spawning fish habitat.

projectDescription:
American Rivers, working in partnership with NOAA, the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, and the Friends of the Patapsco Valley State Park, has restored migratory fish species habitat within the Patapsco River through the removal of the Bloede Dam. The 34-foot high by 220-foot long, state-owned Bloede Dam was a documented safety hazard located within the Patapsco Valley State Park and a major limiting factor in sustainable migratory fish populations in the Patapsco River.  Removal of the Bloede Dam was the linchpin of a larger effort to remove four mainstem dams on the Patapsco River aimed at restoring upstream spawning habitat for river herring and other migratory species.  This project resulted in a free-flowing system and the restoration of the natural form and function of the lower Patapsco River.  The Patapsco River Restoration project kicked off with the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 with funding to remove the Simkins and Union Dams, located upstream from Bloede Dam.  Bloede Dam was the first blockage on the Patapsco River and key to restoring fish passage access to the watershed.

Additional funding and accomplishment information for this project can be found under CRP Project Record 4001.
primaryStrategy: Fish Passage
name: Patapsco River Restoration - Bloede Dam Removal

projectDescription:
In 2013 a Fisheries disaster was declared due to low Chinook salmon returns to Cook Inlet. Opening up fish passage in this area would remove fish passage as a limitation on Chinook salmon survival in the Kenai Peninsula. Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) returning to the Kenai River support one of the largest sport fisheries in Alaska as well as commercial fisheries and processing.

The Kenai Peninsula Aquatic Ecosystem Restoration Project addresses restoration plan goals by eliminating four human-caused barriers to fish and aquatic species passage on the Anchor and Kasilof Rivers:

•	Location:  Crooked Creek at Sterling Hwy. Mile Post 110.5, ADFG Barrier ID # 20300979
•	Location: North Fork Anchor River at Sterling Hwy Mile Post ~157,  ADFG Barrier ID # 20300988 
•	Location: Two Moose Creek – Tributary Anchor River at Sterling Hwy Mile Post 159, Sterling Highway ADFG Barrier ID # 20300989
•	Location: North Fork Anchor River at Nikolaevsk Road Mile 0,  ADFG Barrier ID # 20300985

The four barriers identified in this Project request represent the last significant known aquatic species barriers needing to be addressed on the Kenai Peninsula. $8 million in funds for this project were provided by the Exxon Valdez Trustee Council and this was matched by AK DOT. These actions have reconnected fragmented habitat and restored aquatic species access to nearly 95 miles of stream and riparian habitat.

projectDescription: Throughout early 2008, various response actions were being taken throughout San Francisco Bay due to the M/V Cosco Busan oil spill.  One such response action – the barging in of rock through Keil Cove, Marine County resulted in a grounding scar that caused injury to eelgrass located in the northeast corner of the cove.  At the time NRDA was eager to implement emergency restoration actions.  However, the landowners were not willing to allow restoration to occur.  So an agreement was made to only monitor the site with sidescan and multibeam to determine the degree of injury and monitor recovery.  If the site had not recovered, restoration would take place.  After reviewing multiple years of sidescan/multibeam images, it was concluded that the surrounding eelgrass had moved into the scar and was fully recovered by 2014.

projectDescription: The Theodore Roosevelt Audubon Sanctuary Coastal Forest Restoration was completed via cooperative-agreement between the Mattiace Petrochemical Trustees and NYS Audubon. the project repaired and enhanced woodland patches overrun by invasive vines at the nation's first Audubon Sanctuary. The 5 acre woodland enhancement was accomplished by removing invasive species in the under-story via a variety of chemical and biological methods, followed by planting of native species.  The understory was dominated by Norway maple, English ivy, vinca, Pachysandra and Japanese spurge.  Removal was initially attempted using two applications of herbicide, with biological and manual labor. Native species such as downy serviceberry, flowering dogwood, white oak, swamp white oak, American holly, sweet pepperbush, joe-pye weed, and broom sedge were planted.  Project funding from NOAA was matched with funds from NFWF and additional matching funds and in-kind services from Restaino Design; a David Workman grant; the Charles Piper Cot Award Internship, the Chingos Foundation, and Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary and Audubon Center.  Approximately $19,812 was to be spent on the purchase of plants and supplies, $38,500 on 2 contractual applications of herbicide, and up to $15,063.27 for staff time for mechanical invasive treatment and planting and maintenance of native species. The Sanctuary employed Green Goats Inc. The goats were partially successful in managing English Ivy.

projectDescription: The 9-acre Halby Chemical Co. site is located in Port of Wilmington in New Castle, Delaware. From 1948 to 1980, a chemical manufacturing plant operated on 3 acres of the site. Site operators discharged wastewater from the plant into an unlined lagoon. Wastewater containing chemicals flowed through an adjacent tidal marsh, through the Lobdell Canal, and into the Christina River. These activities contaminated sediment, soil, surface water and groundwater. The NRDA settlement consisted of the 2003 purchase of 248 acre degraded Cleaver Marsh and transfer of title to DNREC; installation of osprey nesting structures; and purchase of herbicide and application costs ($58,500) to DNREC. The Cleaver Marsh is an island on the “Appaquinimink River east of Odessa, Delaware. The March 2003 draft Natural Resources Trustee Position on a Covenant Not To Sue for the Halby Chemical Company Superfund Site, refers to the Cleaver Marsh as 90 percent dominated by Phragmites australis. 223 acres of phragmites was eradicated and restored o a Spartina alterniflora dominated marsh.  The document also stated, “It is fully anticipated with Phragmites control and reintroduction of Spartina alternaflora, that fisheries habitat quality and quantity will increase primarily through the re-development of tidal guts and pools within this marsh." The treatment of the marsh with herbicide became a routine (yearly) part of operations and management through the rest of the decade.

projectDescription:
The Anzhela Explorer, a 78 foot steel-hulled motorized catamaran, sank off the coast of southeast Florida adjacent to Golden Beach, Miami-Dade County on 26 March 2007. The vessel initially sank on the shallow, nearshore reef and was then pushed shoreward across the reef a distance of approximately 366 meters, by the very rough seas that were occurring at the time of the sinking. As a result of the vessel sinking, extensive physical (fractured and gouged reef structure), and biological (broken and dislodged reef biota including hard and soft corals and sponges) injuries occurred on the reef. The initial triage and salvage of living hard and soft corals was conducted during 29 March-1 May 2007, with subsequent reattachment of the organisms during early June 2007. This work was conducted by a team comprised of local, state and federal diving scientists.

The second phase of the restoration plan included the management and stabilization of the significant amount of rubble material created as a result of the vessel grounding. The State trustees contracted with Sea Byte Inc. to conduct the rubble related portions of the restoration effort.Work related to rubble stabilization was conducted on the injury site in two phases. The initial phase consisted of a mapping and rubble collection effort and the second phase consisted of rubble stabilization and habitat reconstruction effort.
primaryStrategy: Coral
name: M/V Anzhela Explorer - Coral Reef Restoration

projectDescription: The DuPont Newport NRDA Trustees, DNREC, NOAA, and USFWS, were authorized to recover damages to trust resources associated with a release of a hazardous waste at the DuPont Newport site. USFWS led this project located on the Mispillion River in Kent County, Delaware, in order to compensate the public for natural resources injuries stemming from hazardous waste releases at the DuPont manufacturing facility in Newport DE.  An eroded, degraded marsh has been transformed into vital habitat for local wildlife. The 56-acre private site consists of one of the river's original meanders and associated wetland with more than 2,000 feet of river frontage. Large timbers were placed end to end along a half-mile run of the Mispillion River near Milford DE in order to slow or halt the erosion of the tidal marsh. The project was completed in Oct 2008 and monitored through June 2012. The Mispillion marshes had degraded in the 50 years since the navigation channel was realigned and straightened.  The oxbow channel had filled in and the marsh was colonized by Common Reed (Phragmites australis), an invasive plant. The western edge of the marsh was severely eroded due to boat wakes. To slow erosion large timbers were anchored end to end along 2,000 ft of shore and the oxbow was dredged and deepened. The sediment cast into the marsh through a technique known as thin layer spreading.

projectDescription:
The objectives for restoration at this site were to (1) improve Helmet Creek, restore juvenile and adult fish passage, (2) improve water quality, and (3) allow for improved habitat for salmonid species. The Trustees considered various alternative projects to address these restoration goals, which are outlined in this DARP/EA. After reviewing these alternatives, the Trustees agreed that the proposed restoration alternative could best meet their objectives. The following restoration was chosen and implemented

1) Removed two trash racks from culverts in Helmet Creek. Removing these barriers opened up  approximately 5,000 squared meters of new salmon habitat.
2) Monitoring control structures on the Creek to ensure they maximize fish passage.
3) Restored grade of creek for fish passage, 
4) Improved low flow passage by capping a side channel culvert above the tank farm,
5) Removed debris from the creek and floodplain, 
6) Revegetated banks to minimize disturbance and provide bank stability.
primaryStrategy: Fish Passage
name: Helmet Creek Fish Passage Project

projectDescription: Beginning in 2012, the Montrose Settlements Restoration Program (MSRP) will provide annual funding for the MDRA Youth Fishing Project through the Education and Outreach Mini-Grant Program.  The funding supports boat charter costs for youth (ranged from 10 ‐16 years of age) from at‐risk environments in the Los Angeles area.  The Marina Del Rey Anglers (MDRA), a local recreational fishing organization, will coordinate and staff youth fishing trips that will depart  from Marina Del Rey Harbor and head out to the Santa Monica Bay. Youth will spend time fishing in the Santa Monica Bay and learn about safe fishing practices. Each session on the fishing vessel will include an educational session about local fish contamination and safe fishing practices using visual aids, as well as instruction on how to fish. Fishing staff on the boat will also show the kids and counselors how to properly fillet a fish for the safest possible consumption. Copies of the MSRP Comic Book and Fish Identification Card will be distributed to the children to take home and to share with their friends and families. Post surveys for youth and counselor participants will be completed off-site and then returned by mail to the MDRA Project Manager.

projectDescription:
SEA Lab educates students on the benefits of recreational fishing, fish contamination, alternatives to consuming contaminated fish species, fish identification, proper handling and releasing of fish, proper preparation of fish for consumption, and pier fishing through interactive games, hands-on activities and educational presentations. SEA Lab has been awarded grants for six funding cycles, so far. This project covers the funding years of 2010-2014.  

Students are transported from their schools to the SEA Lab for a three hour hands-on field trip. While at SEA Lab students participate in an interactive game focused on food chains that shows how DDTs and PCBs have impacted the environment. This activity is followed by a hands-on guided tour of the salt-water tanks that house different species of fish where students learn how to identify fish and about how fishing regulations are established by studying the species’ life history.  

The second part of the field trip consists of a fishing excursion at the Hermosa Beach Pier. They are taught basic fishing techniques and proper fish handling. Students learn how to interpret fish consumption health advisories. They also observe a fish fillet demonstration and learn preparation methods to limit their exposure to contaminants.
primaryStrategy: Does not fall under a strategy
name: Montrose - SEA Lab/Los Angeles Conservation Corp - Fun Fishing Program

projectDescription: The City of Los Angeles Department of Recreation and Parks (LADRP) conducts the Cabrillo Beach Pier Fishing Project (CBPFP) during June/July each year by providing four-hour long sessions for youth ages 6-16 years. The program educates youth about safe fish consumption along the Los Angeles coastline, explains the impact of human activity on the Palos Verdes Shelf (PVS) ecosystem, and provides a safe hands-on fishing experience. Each four-hour session includes four phases: a tour of the Cabrillo Marine Aquarium, an educational lesson incorporating games and MSRP outreach materials, a hands-on fishing activity referencing local coastal fish consumption advisories. All participants receive a post survey to assess the knowledge they have gained and their level of enjoyment and interest in future fishing related activities.

projectDescription: The site is a former 86-acre municipal landfill in the Cramer Hill neighborhood of Camden, New Jersey, at the intersection of Harrison Avenue and East State Street where the Cooper River flows into the Delaware River. There were four main components to the Cramer Hill Waterfront Park design: landfill closure, shoreline protection, habitat restoration, and recreational park amenities.  The completed waterfront park includes features such as an amphitheater, an entry plaza, exercise stations, a fishing plaza, hiking/biking paths and trails, historic/educational signage, a kayak launch, a picnic area, a playground, a sensory garden, shoreline observation areas, and a vista summit with panoramic views of Camden, the Delaware River, and Philadelphia. Habitat restoration involved enhancing and expanding the existing freshwater wetlands by constructing approximately 7 acres of tidal freshwater wetlands on both the Cooper and Delaware Rivers, creating 3 living shoreline areas along the back channel of the Delaware River, preserving three areas of existing trees as bald eagle forage habitat, re-planting trees within the remainder of the bald eagle forage habitat including an area where large, specimen trees were planted. Over 375,000 plantings were included in the project. The tidal freshwater wetland on the Cooper River  connects to a fishing pond that is a prominent feature of the waterfront park.

projectDescription: Fucus distichus (aka gardneri) is an intertidal seaweed (rockweed) that has been shown to be negatively impacted by oil spills. Two oil spills have occurred in the San Francisco Bay Area in the past 10 years. Before beginning restoration of Fucus in the bay by transplanting remnant individuals to affected areas for "reseeding",  the genetic structure of local  populations was assessed to ensure that natural genetic boundaries were not manipulated. Specific genetic structure of Fucus was found within the bay but genetics were not different enough between local sites/populations to require donor individuals to be taken from extremely proximal transplant sites. Rather, it was decided that donor Fucus be taken from Golden Gate Fields and transplanted to Point Isabel for the first stage (trial) of restoration. After monitoring in 2018/2019 there was a decline in the transplants.  It was decided that a new site would have to be established.  In the fall of 2020 new transplants were placed at Giant Marsh/ Richmond, CA.  Monitoring will continue into 2021.  See monitoring section for results.
primaryStrategy: Does not fall under a strategy
name: Cosco Busan Oil Spill- Rockweed Restoration
darrpResponsibility: M/V Cosco Busan, LR/IMO; Regal Stone Limited, Fleet Management Limited, John Cota

projectDescription: MassAudubon manages the 595-acre Allens Pond Wildlife Sanctuary in Dartmouth, MA The Buzzards Bay Trustee Council (BBTC) funded this invasive plant management and trail improvement project as a Tier 1-preferred alternative through its 2014 Final Restoration Plan and Environmental Assessment (Project LU-5). Dense, non-native Phragmites australis (common reed) patches occur in several places at the Sanctuary; two areas are targeted for control. In both these areas, plants exceed three meters in height, obscure views of the shore and bay, create a monoculture, and threaten to further encroach into wildlife habitats. Along the east side of the sanctuary, common reed forms a fringe along the boundary between the salt marsh and a former corn field that has been restored to a warm-season grassland with a perimeter trail. The tall, invasive plant grows between the edge of the grassland and the salt marsh, and thus disrupts continuity of the plant community structure that is highly beneficial to wildlife. MassAudubon will use both herbicide and mechanical removal. Initial treatment will take place at the end of the growing season with foliar application of a formulation of glyphosate that is approved for use in wetlands. Licensed applicators will spray standing plants in September and early October when plants are actively moving nutrients into the root rhizomes. MassAudubon is also constructing a public trail project including an all-persons access trail.
primaryStrategy: Does not fall under a strategy
name: Allens Pond Public Access and Invasive Plant Control

projectDescription: MSRP and the Luckenbach Trustee Councils combined resources to support a five year program restoring seabird habitat on several Baja California Pacific Islands. Seabird species such as the California Brown Pelican, Cassin?s Auklet, Ashy Storm-Petrel, and Xantus?s Murrelet nest on the Baja California Pacific Islands. These seabirds face threats from non-native species; nest and burrow destruction in high use areas; and disturbances from lights and other man-made structures. The restoration partners will conduct habitat restoration, reduce human disturbance and artificial light, and support environmental education in surrounding communities. To increase nesting seabird populations on the islands, scientists will use decoys, mirrors, and broadcast calls and songs to attract seabirds and construct artificial nests to improve nesting opportunities.

projectDescription: The Common Murre Restoration Project is a comprehensive seabird restoration effort aimed at enhancing depleted seabird populations in central California, specifically those of the common murre (Uria aalge). The main focus of the project is to reestablish a colony of murres on a small seastack called Devil's Slide Rock, located along the San Mateo coast near Pacifica. This breeding colony held close to 3,000 murres as recently as the early 1980s, but was wiped out as a result of human-caused mortality.  The Project employs a technique called social attraction to lure birds back to Devils Slide Rock.  Social attractants including decoys of adult murres, decoys of mature chicks and eggs, CD players projecting amplified murre sounds, and three-sides mirror boxes are being used to attract the highly colonial birds back to the rock.

projectDescription:
Eelgrass transplants for COSCO Busan DARP were initiated in 2014, 2015, and 2016. Transplants were postponed in 2017 due to flooding impacts. 
 Low to salinities  during the spring  caused considerable eelgrass dieback in both transplants and donor locations.  In 2018, eelgrass transplants  were again postponed.   The total transplanted eelgrass for the three transplant years has been 9.4 acres.  This has been concentrated in San Rafael Bay, Corte Madera Bay, and Richardson Bay.  Richardson Bay has performed best due steady increases in area even while sites in San Rafael Bay declined precipitously with the freshwater impact of 2017 and subsequently recovered somewhat, but not completely in 2017 and 2018.  The spatial distribution of eelgrass transplants have reached a peak of 8.45 acres.  The transplanted eelgrass in Richardson Bay was also used as spawning substrate by herring in 2017‐2018.   This was the first record of the recent transplants being used by herring.   Eelgrass transplanting and monitoring is ongoing until 2022.

projectDescription: This project involves the removal of invasive species and replanting of native plant species at the Boundary Channel area within George Washington Memorial Park. The Potomac River Boundary Channel Restoration Project (Boundary Channel) is located on the west side of the Potomac River adjacent to the Pentagon just north of Roaches Run Waterfowl Sanctuary. The 100-foot-wide channel connects the Potomac River and Pentagon Lagoon between Columbia Island and Arlington, Virginia. The Boundary Channel property has undergone undesirable changes from the establishment of invasive non-native species. The upland habitat consists mainly of a monoculture mat of Ampelopsis and other invasive vines. This project will remove non-native invasive plants from both sides of the entire length of shoreline and adjacent uplands. Cleared areas will then be replanted with native shrubs, grasses, and flowers beneficial to wildlife. The Trustees estimate that 11,000 linear feet of improved shoreline, 4 acres of riparian forested/shrub habitat and 7 acres of upland grassland meadow/shrub habitat will be restored through this project.

projectDescription:
The project replaced five undersized culverts on public road crossings along Crooked Brook and its tributaries in Charleston, Maine, opening upwards of 12.6 miles of stream habitat.  Crooked Brook is a headwaters tributary of Kenduskeag Stream, which enters the Penobscot River in Bangor, Maine just upstream of the Chevron Site.  Crooked Brook and its tributaries are important habitat for native wild brook trout and diadromous fish like blueback herring, American eel and sea lamprey, prime juvenile rearing areas for Atlantic salmon, and are cold-water habitats that are expected to support these species into the future even under projected climate changes.

Three of the five road crossings are located on the mainstem of Crooked Brook and the two additional road crossings are on two separate unnamed tributaries of Crooked Brook.  Together, replacing these five road crossings opened up approximately 12.6 miles of stream habitat in the Crooked Brook watershed (4.1 miles along the mainstem Crooked Brook, 2 miles in one unnamed tributary and 6.45 miles in a second unnamed tributary).
primaryStrategy: Fish Passage

projectDescription: Parker Pond is a 66-acre pond located in Brooksville in the headwaters of Mill Stream, a tributary of the Bagaduce River.  Parker Pond historically supported large runs of returning alewives that completely stopped a few decades ago.  An existing earthen berm remained, and a former water level control structure is no longer in place. A combination of historic mill remnants in the stream and beaver dams built opportunistically created a series of complex flows and sharp drops that were too difficult for migrating alewives to navigate.  The project restored fish passage to Parker Pond by constructing a nature-like fishway (riffle) at the former dam location in 2021.  At the outlet of a large meadow downstream of Parker Pond, the constructed riffle also retained water levels for high value wetlands, including state-designated significant wading bird and waterfowl habitat.  The project included final design, permitting, construction and monitoring (implementation monitoring and fish monitoring).

projectDescription: To compensate for injuries and interim losses sustained by wetlands, waterfowl, wading birds, and shorebirds, the Trustees proposed to enhance the productivity of a specific area of a salt marsh in Scarborough, Maine.  Scarborough Marsh is located on the northwestern and southeastern sides of U.S. Highway 1  (US 1).  The Trustees undertook a hydrological assessment of the Dunstan River Marsh to determine the most ecologically beneficial method for enhancing the site.  The assessment evaluated tidal hydrology both upstream and downstream of US 1, determined the degree of tidal restriction caused by the road, evaluated freshwater input to the system; and provided recommendations for restoring the natural hydrology of the system.  Options that the Trustees evaluated for restoring the marsh include adding an additional culvert under US 1, creating pannes and new tidal channels, and removing fill. projectDescription:
In spring 2019, 350 oyster reef elements were placed in nearshore areas to create a living shoreline near Giant Marsh at Point Pinole Regional Shoreline managed by East Bay Regional Park District in the City of Richmond.  Eelgrass beds were planted next to the reefs to create a habitat ideal for the recruitment of native Olympia oysters and other aquatic species.
The three million dollar project is partially funded through the Cosco Busan settlement funds through the NFWF agreement and by the State Coastal Conservancy, the Ocean Protection Council, and the US Fish and Wildlife Service.  
The Giant Marsh project is one of a number of living shoreline projects taking place in the San Francisco Bay, but the only that connects the submerged underwater habitats with adjacent wetlands and upland ecotone plant communities. 
The project will be monitored by the Coastal Conservancy to gather data on the success of native oyster establishment and future eelgrass plantings, and to construct the additional tidal marsh and upland transition zone plantings. Native oysters are a keystone species that support fish, crabs, bird and other wildlife populations, many of which were impacted by the Cosoc Busan oil spill in 2007.

projectDescription: Walker Pond is a 693-acre pond in the headwaters of the Bagaduce River.  It lies near the town lines of Sedgwick and Brooksville, Maine.  There was a stretch of earthen berm at the outlet, a road crossing, and remnants of a large former mill site and associated dam.  The dam was a large stone, wood and concrete structure, about 10-feet high with a 9-foot spillway, with an existing bypass channel/fishway that needed improvement.  A better fishway was designed for this location to greatly increase the alewife run and reduce the maintenance burden currently required, while also retaining and respecting the heritage of the mill site.  A feasibility study was conducted in 2018 to evaluate alternatives for this site, which consisted of stabilization of the existing dam, enhancement of the existing nature-like fishway to increase the capacity, and modifications to sections of the dam and immediately downstream to protect out-migrating fish, especially juvenile alewives.  The project proceeded through final design, permitting and construction, and included increased capacity of the upstream passage channel, a new exit structure, new downstream passage chutes and plunge pools, water level controls (stoplogs) and a new dry hydrant for firefighting water supply.  After fish passage improvements were completed in 2020, the site was turned into a municipally-owned park with public access and interpretive signage about the site's history and ecology of the alewife run.
primaryStrategy: Fish Passage
name: Walker Pond Fish Passage (Bagaduce River)

projectDescription: The primary goal of this program is to improve the nesting success of California's resident breeding seabird species (especially surface nesting species such as commom murres) and improve the quality of roosting habitat by reducing disturbance at their breeding and roosting colonies. Breeding seabirds, particularly seabirds that nest on cliffs or offshore rocks, are highly susceptible to the negative impacts caused by human disturbance. When disturbance events occur, the birds may flee from their nests, leaving their eggs and chicks unprotected from predators and adverse weather conditions. In addition, the eggs or chicks may be accidentally knocked off rocks or cliffs when the birds flee. The trustees will implement a multipronged education, outreach, and enforcement program targeting disturbance events from aircraft overflights and other recreational and fishing activities.
primaryStrategy: Does not fall under a strategy
name: M/T Command Oil Spill - Seabird Colony Protection Program
darrpResponsibility: Pearl Shipping Corp. and Anax International Agencies, Inc.

projectDescription: The Sooty Shearwater Restoration Project will protect and enhance their nesting habitat by eradicating non-native rats from breeding areas on nesting grounds in New Zealand. The rats, believed to have been brought to the islands in the 1960s by fishing boats, have devastating the island's flora and fauna, including sooty shearwaters. The three main objectives of this project were to eliminate rodents from four shearwater breeding islands, thereby eliminating egg and chick predation; establish quarantine contingencies to prevent reintroduction of rats to restored island colonies; and monitor restoration progress and project effectiveness.
primaryStrategy: Does not fall under a strategy
name: M/T Command Oil Spill - Sooty Shearwater Restoration Project
darrpResponsibility: Pearl Shipping Corp. and Anax International Agencies, Inc.

projectDescription: This project will restore critical nonbreeding pelican habitat by enhancing and protecting coastal roosts along the central California mainland. Specifically, this project will target improvements to the roost site at Breakwater Island, located in San Francisco Bay adjacent to Alameda. This is the largest roosting area and the only known night roost in the San Francisco Bay area (U.S. Navy 1997). It is used primarily in late summer through fall?July through November or December?when the pelicans move northward from breeding areas in southern California and Mexico. Methods to protect this roost include placing buoys to keep boaters a safe distance from the island, installing signs, developing public outreach and education programs, and adding enforcement patrols.
primaryStrategy: Does not fall under a strategy
name: M/T Command Oil Spill - Brown Pelican Roost Site Enhancement and Protection Project
darrpResponsibility: Pearl Shipping Corp. and Anax International Agencies, Inc.

projectDescription: At Half Moon Bay State Beach, the proposed project involves improving beach access and protecting natural resources by constructing a stairway to the beach. The stairway will improve public access to the coastline and protect natural resources. CDPR will design and construct the stairs and walkway to enhance coastal access. By defining appropriate pathways and beach access points, CDPR can eliminate a network of informal paths that have caused erosion and damage to sensitive resources. For example, trails and access points will be directed away from the nesting area of the western snowy plover.

projectDescription:
The Indian Creek Natural Resource Restoration and Conservation project ("Indian Creek) will restore, enhance, and preserve several types of habitats endemic to the Lower Cape Fear region along 1.75 miles of Indian Creek, a tributary of the Cape Fear River. Over 142 acres of high-quality tidal freshwater marsh and tidal cypress-gumswamp and 40 acres of 100-foot buffers along Indian Creek and Moll’s Branch will be protected in perpetuity along this corridor through conservation instruments. Restoration along Moll's Creek includes roadbed removal, bank stabilization and native species planting. The project also includes public access components such as improvements to an existing boat ramp and the installation of a fixed pier alongside the ramp.
The Indian Creek project is one of ten projects included in Phase 1 Restoration for the Kerr-McGee Chemical Corp NRDA case in Navassa, North Carolina.

name: Indian Creek Natural Resource Restoration and Conservation

projectDescription: Hurricane Mathew passed south of Puerto Rico in October 2016 generating large storm waves that impacted a large stand of the ESA listed elkhorn coral (Acropora palmata) off of Guanica on the south coast of Puerto Rico.  The large waves damaged many of the elkhorn coral colonies and generated thousands of coral fragments. Restoration efforts focused on saving the at-risk fragments that were loose and were likely going to die.  The impacted area has a large healthy population of A. palmata, so fragments were transplanted to other reefs to assist in recovery of elkhorn populations in other areas.  Approximately 8,500 corals were transplanted to 10 different reefs.  Coral fragments were also brought into 4 different nurseries in Guanica and La Parguera to assist with coral propagation efforts.
primaryStrategy: Coral
name: Hurricane Matthew Palmata Damage

projectDescription: The M/V Aubi, a 49’ powered catamaran, ran aground on a coral reef the evening of 14May2015  within a newly established Puerto Rico Marine Reserve in the vicinity of La Cueva del Indio, Arecibo, Puerto Rico (Figure 1).  There were high densities of corals in this area including thickets of Acropora palmata which is listed as Threatened under ESA.  The 8mm thick, aluminum hulls of the vessel contained integrated fuel tanks and the USCG ordered the fuel removed prior to allowing the vessel to be removed to remove all risk of oil spill.  Ultimately 1,500 gallons of fuel were removed from the vessel the evening of 15May2015 and the vessel was pulled free from the reef at 0700 16May2015 by multiple Sea Tow vessels.  NOAA/NOS ERD & ARD and NOAA/NMFS SERO & RC were all closely coordinated during the initial incident response in support of the USCG's successful prevention of an oil spill.  Approximately 1,500 corals, including 100 fragments of Acropora palmata, were reattached during the restoration and 10m3 of material were removed from the site to prevent additional damage to unimpacted areas during swells.
primaryStrategy: Coral
name: M/V Aubi grounding
